text:
- [Instructor] In this
video, I'm gonna talk about
visualizing CloudWatch logs

using the new OpenSearch
dashboard feature.
This new feature allows

direct OpenSearch
visualization within CloudWatch

with no additional
OpenSearch clusters required.
There's zero infrastructure management
and the launch date was December, 2024.

There's a lot of value
with this new integration.

You get advanced log
analysis with zero setup.

You get native integration
with CloudWatch Logs
and it's cost effective.

You only pay for what data
you're ingesting and storing.

There are prebuilt
dashboards for VPC flow logs,
AWS WAF logs and AWS CloudTrail logs.
Keep an eye out, there will be additional
prebuilt dashboards over time.

To enable the CloudWatch
OpenSearch integration,
navigate to CloudWatch,
then go to CloudWatch Logs, Insights.

And from here, click on
Analyze with OpenSearch.

You have this option, Create
OpenSearch Integration.
Click on Settings,
give your integration a name.
Your data retention can be one to 30 days.

You can create a new
role for IAM permissions
or use an existing.

And then you have this option
of who can see the dashboards.

You have specific roles
or you can have all roles.

And for this example,
I'm gonna use all roles.
Then you confirm

and it takes 15 minutes
or so to enable this.

Once you've enabled the
OpenSearch integration,
you can create new dashboards.
Let's go through that.
Create Dashboard.
You have these dashboard types.

You have VPC flow logs,
CloudTrails, and WAF logs.

Keep an eye out, there may be
additional types over time.
You can give it a name.
If you want, a description.

Then you have dashboard
data configuration options.
You have frequency of synchronization
every five minutes or every 15 minutes.

Choosing five minutes
may increase the costs.
Please take a look at the pricing
to make sure you're aware of that.
Then you're gonna select your log groups.
And once you've selected a log group,

you can look at the log samples
to see what that looks like.

Once you're done with
that, Create Dashboard.
Once you have your dashboard created,
you will see the dashboard show up here
and you can navigate through that.
In this example with the VPC demo,

you're seeing traffic patterns,
heat maps by top talkers.

You're gonna see bytes
transferred over time,

packets over time, and then
a series of top talkers.
You're now seeing the CloudTrail dashboard

and here you see how
many events over time,

how many events have happened
in that period of time.

You're seeing by ID, account
ID, categories, regions,
and then your top API events,

and you're gonna get a list
of your generating events.
Just like with any CloudWatch dashboard,

you have various options
about your timeframes
and your refresh rates.
You can refresh every minute
to five or 15 minutes automatically.
You can also narrow down the visible time

in these different increments
or create a custom time
by minutes, hours, days, or weeks.
You can choose between UTC
or your local time zone on the computer.
Additional options are within
each of the dashboards to do filtering.

For example, if you want
to filter by account IDs,
you can then apply changes,

and now you're seeing
just those account IDs.
And just as if with other dashboards,

you can click and select
a particular time range
to narrow down what you're looking at.
In the event that you want to customize

some of these dashboards,
under the Actions button,
there is an option to view in OpenSearch.
This is the standard OpenSearch interface,

and in this, you're looking
at one of the dashboards.
You can edit the dashboard
and at that point you can make changes
to the various elements.
For example, if you wanted to change
the font size on this number,
because maybe the number is too large,
you can come in here under Options,

you can adjust the style of
the font size, hit Apply,
save it, and now that's slightly smaller

just in case you have
a large number there.
At that point, you've saved it

and it will update the dashboard
in the CloudWatch Logs UI.
